thread.title: Corruption Currents: Companies Under Scrutiny for Cohen Payments

author: Ben DiPietro
title: Corruption Currents: Companies Under Scrutiny for Cohen Payments
text:
1 COMMENTS Michael Cohen, personal lawyer for U.S. President Donald Trump, at Trump Tower in New York in December. (Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images) Photo: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Federal prosecutors allege MiMedx Group paid bribes to health-care workers at the Department of Veterans Affairs in return for promoting its products. The company admitted it paid some VA employees. (Bloomberg, SA, release)
Four judges in Ghana were suspended as part of a bribery scandal . The article had no comment from the judges. (TL, Punch)
Lawmakers in Sri Lanka passed legislation to form special courts to handle bribery and corruption cases. (Reuters)
Money Laundering:
The head of Latvia’s new anti-money laundering department wants it to be independent of the country’s Prosecutor General’s office. (LSM)
Authorities in Italy arrested 14 people they say were part of a gang involved in laundering money and financing terrorists. None of the suspects was quoted in the story. (BBC)
How easy is it to launder money in the digital world? (IPP)
A county commissioner in Kansas pleaded not guilty to fraud and money-laundering charges. (AP)
Cybercrime/Data Privacy:
Some security experts expect Iran to launch a cyberattack in retaliation fo r the U.S. reimposing sanctions and leaving the nuclear agreement. (Telegraph, CFR)
Cybersecurity experts and former national security officials expressed concern at the possibility the role of the top cybersecurity official in the White House might be eliminated. The White House didn’t deny the role might go. (Politico, Gizmodo)
A type of cryptocurrency fundraising known as Simple Agreement for Future Tokens, or SAFT, is drawing the attention of regulators. (MW)
Sanctions:
Will sanctions against Iran serve to advance the interests of U.S. President Donald Trump? Companies stand to lose billions of dollars from the U.S. withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal and the reinstatement of sanctions. Traders and refineries are preparing for an end to Iran oil purchases. Europe considers a strategy from the 1990s to thwart the U.S. sanctions. (Reuters, NPR, AP, Axios, Bloomberg, Reuters)
The U.S. Treasury Department on Thursday levied sanctions against several Iranian firms, individuals and officials it said are operating an illegal currency-exchange network in the United Arab Emirates. (WSJ)
The United Nations wants private companies such as insurers and commodities traders to help combat North Korea’s efforts to evade sanctions. (CNBC)
A top U.N. official wants additional sanctions against South Sudan. (AN)
Whistleblowers:
A decision by U.K. regulators not to push for the firing of the chief executive of Barclays PLC after he tried to track down a whistleblower sends a bad message to people considering highlighting wrongdoing. (Forbes)
Transparency:
General Anticorruption:
The former chairman of a big Chinese insurance company was sentenced to prison for fraud, the latest in a series of scandals involving the country’s insurers. (AP)
Drug company Novartis said its payment to Essential Consultants LLC, a company affiliated with Michael Cohen, personal lawyer to U.S. President Donald Trump, was a mistake . A South Korean firm paid Mr. Cohen, too. Some Democrat senators want an investigation into AT&T payments to Mr. Cohen. (Bloomberg, Reuters, CNBC, CNN)
Columbus Nova, an investment-management firm with links to Russian oligarch Viktor Vekselberg—who was questioned by Mr. Mueller—also paid the company. Who is Mr. Vekselberg? (CNN, NBC)
How big a deal are the revelations about Michael Cohen’s business arrangements? Mr. Cohen’s attorneys dispute some of the allegations published by the lawyer for the porn star who claims she slept with the president. The lawyer says Mr. Trump and Mr. Cohen should release their bank records related to their businesses during the time of the 2016 presidential election. Whoever leaked Mr. Cohen’s bank records may face legal trouble. What does the Cohen information say about the state of compliance ? (NYer, BI, WP, Politico, DB, BZ)
U.S. Vice President Mike Pence says it’s time for Robert Mueller to conclude his investigation. He also says Mr. Cohen’s business dealings are a “ private matter .” Mr. Trump told his attorneys he knows nothing about Mr. Cohen’s business activities. (Guardian, Politico, Time)
A U.K. teen-aged girl plotted to bomb the British Museum after her fiance, an ISIS member, was killed in Syria, prosecutors alleged at her trial . (Guardian)
